subject: Art
title: Color Temperature in Painting
description: Warm lights/cool shadows â€” the temperature rule that makes paintings glow.

hook.text: Golden sunlight (warm) creates blue-purple shadows (cool). An overcast day (cool light) creates warm shadows. Light and shadow are ALWAYS opposite temperatures. This rule creates the color harmony that makes paintings vibrate with life.

buildup.text: The principle: if the light source is warm (sunlight, tungsten), shadows lean cool (blue, violet, green). If the light source is cool (overcast, fluorescent), shadows lean warm (orange, red-brown). They complement each other.

discovery.text: Why it works: warm/cool contrast creates visual vibration â€” the colors push against each other optically. Paintings with this temperature contrast feel luminous and alive. Paintings where light and shadow are the same temperature feel flat.

twist.text: Beginners make shadows by adding black. Pros make shadows by adding the COMPLEMENT (cool) of the light color. Shadows aren't the absence of light â€” they're the presence of reflected environment. They have their own color.

climax.text: Paint a simple sphere: warm orange light on the lit side, cool blue-purple in the shadow. Then paint the same sphere with cool blue light and warm orange-brown shadow. Both glow with life because of the temperature contrast.

punchline.text: Warm light, cool shadow. Cool light, warm shadow. This simple rule is the engine of luminous painting.

quiz.question: If a scene is lit by warm sunlight, what color temperature should the shadows lean toward?
